  • Method Details

    • isOrthoNormalTransformationMatrix

      public static boolean isOrthoNormalTransformationMatrix​(RBMatrix transformationMatrixOrthToRaw, RBMatrix covarianceMatrix, Epsilon epsilon)
      Returns true iff a matrix is a valid transformation matrix from orthonormal factor space to raw factor space. A transformation matrix is orthonormal iff, given any two exposure vectors A and B in orthonormal space, it's true that: Variance(A+B) = Variance(A) + Variance(B). Also, where T is the transformation matrix from orth. space to raw space, it should always be true that T' * COVARIANCE * T is equal to the identity matrix. Intuitively, this means that the covariance matrix in ortho-space is the identity matrix If the above is true, then given any two exposures in orthogonal space, it's also true that: Variance(Exposure1) + Variance(Exposure2) = Variance(Exposure1 + Exposure2)

    • computeVariance

      public static double computeVariance​(RBMatrix covarianceMatrix, RBMatrix rawLoadings)
      Given raw loadings and a matrix, compute variance. variance = loadings' * COVMAT * loadings. This helper function is not taking on the responsibility of making sure any properties of the covariance matrix are true. It simply does a multiplication. If the loadings and the covariance matrices passed in are incompatible sizes, this will throw an exception. The only check applied is that rawLoadings has 1 column.

    • isAlmostIdentityMatrix

      public static boolean isAlmostIdentityMatrix​(RBMatrix matrix, Epsilon epsilon)
      Returns true iff a matrix is similar to the identity matrix, to within epsilon.

    • isSymmetricMatrix

      public static boolean isSymmetricMatrix​(RBMatrix rbMatrix, Epsilon epsilon)
      Check if a matrix is symmetric (to within epsilon).

    • isPositiveSemiDefiniteSymmetricMatrix

      public static boolean isPositiveSemiDefiniteSymmetricMatrix​(RBSquareMatrix rbSquareMatrix)
      Check whether a matrix is symmetric and 'positive semi-definite'.

      A matrix M is 'positive semi-definite' if for any vector x:

      x_transpose * M * x >= 0

      'Positive semi-definite' is the matrix equivalent of 'non-negative'. A 'PSD' matrix defines a non-negative vector length, i.e. sqrt(x' * M * x).

      Covariance matrices are symmetric and positive semi-definite. This check ascertains whether a given matrix could be a covariance matrix, at least insofar as a covariance matrix must be PSD.

      This is meant to be a comprehensive check, not an "80/20" check to catch most problems.
